abstract.p: Letter from Dr Alan Matarasso applauds report in June 27 Fashion page article that fashion magazine editors are being called on to restrain using ultra-thin models

block.p: Your June 27 Fashion page article reports that the British Medical Association, in conjunction with fashion magazine editors, has called for restraint in using ultra-thin models in women's magazines. This is an important health and safety mandate that warrants widespread embracement.

Your June 27 Fashion page article reports that the British Medical Association, in conjunction with fashion magazine editors, has called for restraint in using ultra-thin models in women's magazines. This is an important health and safety mandate that warrants widespread embracement.

Repeated exposure to waif-thin people subtly sets a standard that is not naturally feasible for the vast majority of the population to attain. This serves only to reinforce adverse behavior by encouraging eating disorders and the development of unrealistic goals by vulnerable consumers.
ALAN MATARASSO, M.D. New York, June 28, 2000
The writer is associate clinical professor of plastic surgery, Albert Einstein College of Medicine.
